Thank you for continuing to keep me updated. Since we are now in round 11 and your seat is still unfilled, could you please share whether you have received any new indications this round (or last round) that a higher-priority student is likely to apply to School_C soon?

If no higher-priority candidate has reached out or seems likely in the next couple of rounds, I would appreciate being considered as the immediate option to fill the seat—I am still ready to accept immediately and enroll without conditions.

Sincerely,
Student_B

Since repeated [APPLY] attempts have been rejected because they are holding for higher-priority students, the best move this round is [TALK] to elicit concrete information about whether any higher-priority candidates have actually signaled interest or are likely to apply soon, and to position myself as the immediate fallback if not.

conversation.message:
Student_B, thank you for checking in. We have not received any new outreach or specific indication in the last round or this round that a higher-priority student will apply to School_C immediately.

That said, at this stage it is still possible that higher-priority students may become unmatched elsewhere and then apply to us in upcoming rounds, so we are continuing to hold our seat for now rather than making an offer down our list.

If you’d like, you can check back again in a couple of rounds, or submit an [APPLY] later in the process and we will make a formal decision based on the situation at that time.

Student_B has repeatedly applied and been rejected; they are now only asking to talk. Given the market, higher-priority students (D, E, A) all rank School_C as 3rd or worse, so they may come later if rejected elsewhere, but it’s still plausible by round 11. Since Student_B is not top-tier for us and we prefer waiting to maximize chance of matching with D/E/A, we should continue to hold. We should answer transparently: no new indications, but still possible; invite them to check back or apply in later rounds; avoid committing.

conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions Committee,

I’m Student_B. Since School_C remains unfilled in round 12, I would like to formally apply again.

I want to be completely clear: if you offer me the seat this round, I will accept immediately and enroll without conditions.

I understand you are holding the seat in case a higher-priority student applies later, but given that you have not received any specific indications of that happening recently, I respectfully ask you to consider filling the seat now rather than risking it remaining open.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,
Student_B

I have already been rejected multiple times, but School_C has indicated the seat is unfilled and they have no concrete signals of higher-priority applicants. At round 12, the best move is to submit a clear, final-commitment application emphasizing immediate enrollment and the risk of leaving the seat vacant, while remaining respectful of their priority policy.

conversation.message:

After reviewing our priority order and the current state of the process, we are not able to extend an offer to you this round. We are continuing to hold our remaining seat for the possibility that higher-priority students may still become available and apply to School_C in upcoming rounds as outcomes at other schools change.

We appreciate your continued interest, and you are welcome to check back or apply again in a later round.

Student_B is 4th, so accepting them now risks losing the chance to match with Student_D, Student_E, or Student_A if they later become unmatched and apply. Given the broader market, those higher-priority students all rank School_C mid-to-high (D has C as 3rd, E has C as 3rd, A has C as 5th). It remains plausible—especially as other matches shift—that one of D/E/A could become unmatched and then apply to us. With quota 1 and no cost to waiting except potentially ending unmatched, the objective is to maximize priority rank, so I should continue holding the seat and reject Student_B again this round. History shows Student_B will accept immediately, but that does not outweigh priority maximization under the stated objective.

conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions Committee,

Thank you for your continued transparency. Since we are now in round 13 and your seat remains unfilled, could you please clarify what specific condition(s) would cause School_C to stop holding the seat for higher-priority applicants and begin making an offer further down the list?

For example:
1) Is there a particular round number after which you will fill the seat with an applicant who is ready to enroll immediately?
2) Are there specific higher-priority students you still consider realistically likely to become unmatched and apply to School_C (even if you can’t name them, just whether you believe that probability is still meaningful)?

If there is a point at which you would be willing to fill the seat, I want to confirm again that I can accept immediately and enroll without conditions.

Sincerely,
Student_B
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (though lowest). I have already applied many times and been rejected because they are holding the seat for higher-priority students. At round 13, pressing with another APPLY is unlikely to change their decision and may be redundant; a TALK can extract a concrete timeline/trigger for when they would stop holding the seat and consider me, so I can time a final APPLY when it has the highest chance of acceptance.

conversation.message:
Student_B, thank you for the thoughtful questions.

1) **Round threshold:** We do not have a fixed public cutoff, but our current plan is to continue holding the seat for higher-priority students through the mid-rounds, and then reassess in the late stage of the process. Concretely, if we reach approximately **round 24–26** with no higher-priority applicant to School_C materializing, we would be much more likely to begin making an offer further down our list rather than leaving the seat unfilled.

2) **Likelihood of higher-priority applicants:** Yes, we still consider it **meaningfully possible** (though not guaranteed) that a higher-priority student could become unmatched elsewhere as other schools’ seats settle and then apply to School_C. That is the main reason we are still holding the seat at round 13.

If you would like a formal decision at a specific point, you’re welcome to submit an **[APPLY]** again in later rounds (especially closer to that late-stage window), and we will decide based on the situation at that time. You can also check in again around round 18–20 and we can update you on whether our assessment has changed.
conversation.thought: School_C’s true priority is D > E > A > B > C. Student_B is 4th, so accepting now risks losing a chance at D/E/A if they become unmatched and apply later. Student_B is currently only talking, not applying, so no forced accept/reject. Given round 13 (still early vs round 30) and that higher-priority students may be displaced from other schools (especially if School_D reshuffles), it is still rational to hold the seat. Provide a clear policy: we will wait until late rounds (e.g., around 24–26) unless we receive credible info that no higher-priority students remain unmatched/likely to move. Encourage Student_B to check back and/or apply in later rounds for a formal decision then.
